score.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the number of points that each team or player has won in a game or competition
score.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: At half-time the score was one all.
Is anybody keeping score (=making a record of the score)?
The final score was Southampton two, Leeds United nil.
score.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the number of points a student has earned for correct answers in a test
score.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The school’s test scores have not improved.
score.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the number of points that a person or group of people gets in a scientific test or experiment
score.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: He had an IQ score of 120.
score.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a written or printed copy of a piece of music, especially for a large group of performers, or the music itself
score.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Who wrote the score for the movie?
score.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a mark that has been cut onto a surface with a sharp tool
score.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to win a point in a sport, game, competition, or test
score.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Great cheers went up when he scored in the final minute of the game.
She scored an average of 9.9 in the test.
He has scored 12 goals so far this season.
score.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to give a particular number of points in a game, competition, test, or experiment
score.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Each event will be scored separately.
Responses to the individual items are scored on a scale ranging from 0 to 12.
score.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to be very successful in something you do
score.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Her new book has scored a spectacular success.
score.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to have sex with someone, especially someone you have just met
score.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to mark a line on a piece of paper, wood etc using a sharp instrument
score.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Scoring the paper first makes it easier to fold.
score.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to arrange a piece of music for a group of instruments or voices
score.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: The piece is scored for a soprano voice and orchestra.
score.translation[1].definitions[5].note: Score is usually passive in this meaning
score.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to manage to buy or get illegal drugs
score.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a group of 20, or about 20, people or things
score.translation[2].definitions[0].note: three score years and ten old use (=70 years, a person’s expected length of life)
score.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Our coach was escorted by a score of policemen.
